choices.text: Annular hymen

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image is suggestive of the septate hymen.
  • The hymen is the membranous vestige of the junction between the sino-vaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which perforates during fetal life to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum.
  • Defective perforation of this structure may result in the following variants of hymen:
    • Imperforate hymen: Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty)
    • Micro-perforate hymen: Tiny opening
    • Annular hymen: Oval central opening
    • Septate hymen: Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon)
    • Naviculate hymen: Boat-like opening

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imperforate hymen: An imperforate hymen has no opening at all and often presents as cryptomenorrhea (accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen) at puberty.

 

Option B. Semilunar hymen: A semilunar hymen has a crescent-shaped opening and is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Annular hymen: An annular hymen has an oval central opening and does not match the septate appearance in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A septate hymen is characterized by two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue, which may lead to difficulties with intercourse or tampon use.

 

 

Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, he had ascites and auscultation revealed an S3. Which of the following defects can be seen in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tricuspid regurgitation

 

The patient's presentation of bilateral pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, ascites, and an S3 heart sound is indicative of right heart failure. Tricuspid regurgitation leads to right heart failure because it causes blood to back up into the right atrium and subsequently into the systemic venous circulation, resulting in the observed symptoms. Chronic smoking may contribute to pulmonary hypertension, which can exacerbate right heart failure and tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Typically causes left heart failure with symptoms like dyspnea and pulmonary congestion, not right heart failure.

 

Option C. Aortic stenosis: Leads to left ventricular hypertrophy and heart failure, primarily affecting the left side of the heart.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: Primarily affects the left side of the heart and results in pulmonary symptoms and left heart failure rather than right heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tricuspid regurgitation is a common cause of right heart failure, presenting with symptoms such as pedal edema, abdominal distension, and ascites.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive device shown in the photograph: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lippes Loop

 

The contraceptive device shown in the photograph is the Lippes Loop, which is an inert, non-medicated intrauterine device (IUD). The Lippes Loop is categorized as a first-generation IUD and is one of the earliest forms of intrauterine contraception. Unlike modern IUDs, which often contain copper or hormones, the Lippes Loop does not contain any active substances.

 

It is made of plastic and has a distinctive S-shape, which was designed to fit within the uterus. However, due to its high failure rate compared to newer, medicated IUDs, it is not commonly used today. Modern IUDs are typically either copper-based (second-generation) or hormone-releasing (third-generation), which offer better efficacy and safety profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper T 380 A: This is a second-generation IUD that contains copper. It is more effective than the Lippes Loop due to its medicated nature, which creates an inflammatory reaction toxic to sperm and eggs, preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Options B. Mirena and D. Levonorgestrel IUD (LNG-IUD): Mirena is a third-generation, hormone-releasing IUD that contains levonorgestrel, measuring 32 × 32 mm placed for up to 5 years

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lippes Loop is an older, non-medicated, inert IUD that was once widely used but has been largely replaced by more effective copper and hormone-releasing IUDs in modern contraceptive practice.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: Which metal causes the endemic peripheral vascular disease known as Blackfoot disease?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation
  • Below picture shows Blackfoot disease:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antimony: Antimony does not cause Blackfoot disease. It can cause other toxic effects but is not specifically linked to peripheral vascular disease.

 

Option C. Barium: Barium toxicity is primarily associated with gastrointestinal and muscular symptoms rather than peripheral vascular disease.

 

Option D. Cadmium: While cadmium can cause peripheral vascular disease, it does not specifically lead to Blackfoot disease, which is uniquely associated with arsenic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blackfoot disease, characterized by darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs, is specifically caused by chronic arsenic poisoning. Other heavy metals such as cadmium, lead, and mercury can cause peripheral vascular disease, but Blackfoot disease is unique to arsenic exposure.

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pre-gestational diabetes

 

Explanation

 

The image shows a condition known as mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia, which is a rare congenital deformity characterized by the fusion of the lower limbs. This condition is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome) is strongly linked to maternal pre-gestational diabetes.
  • Overt diabetes mellitus during pregnancy is known to cause various congenital anomalies, with cardiac anomalies being the most common, specifically ventricular septal defects (VSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes typically occurs later in pregnancy and does not usually cause congenital anomalies, as organogenesis is largely complete by the time gestational diabetes is diagnosed.

 

Option C. Effect of valproate: Valproate exposure during pregnancy is associated with neural tube defects, facial anomalies (such as cleft lip and palate), and cardiac anomalies, but not sirenomelia.

 

Option D. Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers reduce fetal renal perfusion, leading to conditions such as oligohydramnios and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia, but they do not cause sirenomelia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-gestational diabetes is associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies, including mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia), characterized by the fusion of lower limbs.

 

Ref: Page 384, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding KF ring? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement

2. Is pathognomonic for Wilson's disease

3. Resolves with desferrioxamine

4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement

5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 5 only.

 

Statement 1: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is frequently seen in patients with neurological involvement due to Wilson’s disease, but it may not be present in all cases.

 

Statement 5: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is a copper deposit seen at the superior and inferior poles of the corneal Descemet's membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: While the KF ring is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, it is not solely pathognomonic because it can appear in other chronic cholestatic liver conditions.

 

Statement 3: Desferrioxamine is used for iron chelation and is not effective for copper removal in Wilson's disease. Treatment for copper overload involves agents like penicillamine or trientine.

 

Statement 4: Not all patients with hepatic involvement due to Wilson's disease will have visible KF rings, as their presence correlates more strongly with the duration and severity of copper accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

KF can be seen in disorders causing chronic cholestasis. Seen in ~99% of patients with neuro wilson's, 44-60% with hepatic involvement.

 

Desferioxamine is chelating agent in iron toxicity. 

 

Reference - Harrison/Liver/Wilsons/Chap 344

questions.text: Mineral deficiency clinically found to be associated with sexual dysfunction is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Zinc

 

Zinc deficiency is well-documented to be associated with several reproductive and sexual health issues. It is particularly known for causing Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, a rare genetic disorder.

 

Zinc deficiency can lead to sexual infantilism, sterility, diarrhea, brittle nails, loss of taste, growth failure, etc. Additionally, zinc is crucial for maintaining healthy testosterone levels, which is vital for sexual health in both men and women.

 

In pregnancy, zinc deficiency can result in low birth weight, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), congenital malformations, and even spontaneous abortions, further highlighting its critical role in reproductive health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molybdenum: Molybdenum deficiency is associated with conditions such as mouth or esophageal cancer and respiratory and neurological issues. There is no direct link between molybdenum deficiency and sexual dysfunction.

 

Option B. Copper: Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, bone fractures, neutropenia, osteoporosis, depigmentation of the skin, and thyroid issues. However, it is not linked to sexual dysfunction.

 

Option D. Magnesium: Magnesium deficiency is primarily associated with irritability, tetany, hyperreflexia, and impaired metabolism of potassium and calcium. It does not have a direct connection with sexual dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sexual dysfunction occur due to deficiency of Zinc, calcium, Vitamin D and B12. Essential fatty acid deficiency may also be associated with sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: Although Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 are derived from the same gene but are finally translated into separate proteins. This is mainly due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing

 

Explanation:

 

The difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 is due to RNA editing. In the intestine, a specific cytidine in the mRNA for Apo B is deaminated to uridine, which changes the codon from one encoding amino acid to a stop codon. This results in the production of a shorter protein, Apo B 48. In the liver, this editing does not occur, so the full-length Apo B 100 is produced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA Gene Mutation in Intestines: Incorrect. The difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 is not due to a DNA gene mutation specific to the intestines. Both proteins are derived from the same gene, and the variation in their production is not the result of a DNA mutation.

 

Option B. Point Mutation in Liver: Incorrect. Similarly, the production of these two forms of apolipoprotein B is not due to a point mutation in the liver. The liver produces Apo B 100, but this is not because of a mutation in the hepatic DNA.

 

Option C. DNA Gene Splicing: Incorrect. While alternative splicing is a common mechanism in generating protein diversity, it is not the process responsible for the difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Apo-B-48 is the major apoprotein of chylomicrons.
  • It is synthesized only in the intestinal cells.
  • Apo-B100 and apo-B48 are products of the same gene, but in the intestine, the mRNA undergoes editing and so produces the B48 protein.
  • It is named so because it is only 40% of the size of B100.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 249

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the chest x-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cannonball metastases

 

Explanation

 

The chest x-ray shows multiple round, well-defined nodules distributed throughout the lung fields. These nodules are characteristic of cannonball metastases, which are metastatic lesions typically arising from primary cancers such as renal cell carcinoma, choriocarcinoma, or other malignancies that spread hematogenously to the lungs.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Septic emboli: These typically present with multiple small nodules with a predilection for the lung periphery and often cavitate.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Commonly presents with apical lesions, cavitary lesions, or a miliary pattern, not with multiple well-defined round nodules.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: Appears as a localized area of consolidation with a possible air-fluid level indicating cavitation.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Cannonball metastases present as multiple round, well-defined nodules scattered throughout the lung fields on chest x-ray, indicative of metastatic spread.

choices.text: Yolk sac tumor
Granulosa cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following tumors shows the following finding? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Yolk sac tumor

 

The image shows the characteristic Schiller Duval body which is consistent with yolk sac tumor.

 

  • Endodermal sinus tumor or yolk sac tumor is the second most common germ cell tumor
  • Frequently seen in children and young women.
  • The tumor is usually unilateral but may metastasise to the other ovary.
  • It is a highly aggressive and rapidly growing tumor.
  • Grossly, the tumor is nonencapsulated, and on cross-section shows homogeneous, yellow-white, mucinous appearance.
  • Characteristic on microscopic examination
    • Lacelike (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal or flattened cells.
    • Papillary structures, solid cords of cells, and a multitude of other less common patterns may be found.
    • Schiller-Duval bodies may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli.
    • Present within and outside the cytoplasm are eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules in which α- fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin can be demonstrated by immunocytochemical staining.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminoma (counterpart of seminoma) is a germ cell tumor. Sheets or cords of large clear cells are seen.

 

Option C. Krukenberg tumor: Krukenberg tumor is a secondary ovarian tumor. Characterized by signet ring” mucin-secreting cells.

 

 

Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: Granulosa cell tumor is Composed of mixture of cuboidal granulosa cells and spindled or plump lipid-laden theca cells. Call-Exner bodies are seen.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies is a key diagnostic feature of yolk sac tumors, distinguishing them from other types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

  • Neonatal meningitis is suspected in the given clinical scenario. The most likely causative organism is Streptococcus agalactiae, which is part of group B streptococci.
  • Neonatal meningitis can either have an early or a late start. Late-onset meningitis affects premature infants and is typically caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (primarily S. epidermidis), as well as S. aureus, E. coli, and Klebsiella species. Early-onset meningitis affects newborns within the first 72 hours of life.
  • Group B streptococci are the most common cause of both meningitis and neonatal sepsis, followed by E. coli. However, E. coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis among very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g).

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Asymptomatic meningococcal infections are common. If invasive disease occurs, the clinical spectrum ranges from meningococcal meningitis (which accounts for the majority of cases) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

 

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. Predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. Predominantly meningitic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: Indicated structure gives origin to which of the following fiber (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dentato-rubral

 

The indicated structure in the provided image is the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is the largest and most lateral of these nuclei. It is involved in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers. These fibers project from the dentate nucleus to the red nucleus in the midbrain, playing a crucial role in the coordination of motor movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebello-rubral: Incorrect because while it involves the cerebellum and red nucleus, the correct specific term for the fiber originating from the dentate nucleus is "dentato-rubral."

 

Option B. Cerebello-reticul: Incorrect because this option refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the reticular formation, not specifically involving the dentate nucleus.

 

Option C. Cerebello-vestibul: Incorrect because this refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the vestibular nuclei, which are involved in balance and spatial orientation, not related to the dentate nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers, which project to the red nucleus and are crucial for motor coordination.

choices.text: Located in the thick muscle layer
Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch
Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about baroreceptors? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Located in the thick muscle layer

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer of the carotid bulb of the internal carotid artery (not in the thick muscle layer); where the walls are typically thinner to allow for the detection of pressure changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stretch receptors: Baroreceptors are indeed stretch receptors; they respond to the stretching of the arterial wall as blood pressure changes.

 

Option C. Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch: Afferent fibers from the carotid sinus baroreceptors pass through the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) to the brainstem.

 

Option D. Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure: Baroreceptors are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure; they quickly respond to fluctuations in blood pressure by sending signals to the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer, not in the thick muscle layer, and they are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure, functioning as stretch receptors with afferent fibers passing via the glossopharyngeal nerve.`1

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is monetary benefit quantified? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost benefit analysis

 

Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA): CBA is a method used to evaluate the total costs versus the total benefits of a project or decision in monetary terms. It helps determine whether the benefits of a project or decision outweigh the costs, thereby justifying the investment. This type of analysis assigns a monetary value to all outcomes, allowing for a direct comparison between costs and benefits. For example, the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) might report that it saved $12 million in a given year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost Effective Analysis (CEA): Definition: CEA assesses the relative costs and outcomes (effects) of different courses of action.

 

  • Output: It is measured in non-monetary terms such as health outcomes (e.g., quality-adjusted life years (QALY) saved). For instance, the NTEP might measure its effectiveness by the number of lives saved or the improvement in the quality of life.

 

Option C. Network Analysis: Definition: This is a quantitative method that involves mapping out and analyzing the sequence of activities and events in a project.

 

  • Tools: It includes techniques like Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM).
  • Usage: Network analysis is used to identify the sequence of tasks, the longest path through the project (critical path), and to optimize the project schedule.

 

Option D. Input Output Analysis: Definition: This method examines the relationship between inputs and outputs in an economic system.

 

  • Application: It can include both cost-benefit and cost-effective analyses as it calculates the effects of changing inputs on the outputs. This type of analysis is often used in economics to understand how different sectors of an economy interact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis] - Results of a program analyzed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $

 

CEA [Cost Effective Analysis] - Output of a program analyzed in terms of RESULTS eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.

 

INPUT-OUTPUT ANALYSIS - Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)

 

NETWORK ANALYSIS – It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant Melanoma

 

The given image showing a benign proliferation of Nevus (type of melanocytes) in a child points to diagnosis of congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Characteristics of Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

  • Seen since birth
  • Black-colored palpable lesion with well-defined borders
  • Surface is rough, hair
  • If > 20cm – giant congenital melanocytic nevus
  • Risk of melanoma is present

 

Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) can be associated with various complications, some of which include:

 

  1. Risk of Melanoma: Individuals with CMN have an increased risk of developing melanoma, a type of skin cancer. This risk is particularly higher in cases of giant congenital melanocytic nevi (GCMN)
  2. Neurocutaneous Melanosis: CMN can be linked to neurocutaneous melanosis, a condition where melanocytes are found in the central nervous system. This condition can lead to neurological issues and requires careful monitoring and management
  3. Proliferative Nodules: In some cases, CMN may develop proliferative nodules, which are areas of increased pigmentation and growth within the nevus. These nodules should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: This is characterized by clouding of the lens within the eye, leading to a decrease in vision. It is not related to skin lesions such as a congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Option B: Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) often leads to secondary glaucoma due to vascular malformations affecting eye drainage, with facial involvement increasing the risk.

 

SWS presents clinically as Port wine stain.

 

Port wine stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Managing SWS-related glaucoma requires a multidisciplinary approach and regular eye exams for early detection and vision preservation.

 

Option D. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common form of skin cancer, often associated with long-term sun exposure. It typically appears as a raised, pearly bump and does not usually develop from congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital melanocytic nevi, especially larger ones, carry an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.
  • Monitoring and possibly biopsy of suspicious changes within these nevi are important for early detection of malignant transformation.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page number 75.9 to 75.14 73.2, 73.3

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, has exhibited significant drug resistance over the years. Initially, penicillin was the treatment of choice for gonorrhea. However, the emergence of penicillin-resistant strains necessitated a shift to other antibiotics. Fluoroquinolones were subsequently used, but resistance to these agents also developed. Currently, third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are the recommended treatment. The issue of antibiotic resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a major public health concern, and ongoing surveillance and development of new treatments are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, has not shown significant drug resistance. It remains highly sensitive to penicillin, which is still the first-line treatment for all stages of syphilis.

 

Option B. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown widespread drug resistance. It is typically treated with azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Drug resistance is not a significant issue with donovanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

choices.text: It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors
It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect of tachycardia
It primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles
It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors

 

  • Labetalol is a 3rd generation beta blocker having the property of additional α and β blockade.

  • α1 receptor blockade leads to the relaxation of arterial smooth muscle and leads to vasodilation, The beta 1 blockade also contributes to a fall in blood pressure as it blocks reflex sympathetic stimulation of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect of tachycardia: Is direct acting vasodilators like hydralazine and minoxidil.

 

Option C. It primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles: Could be nitrates because they cause primarily venodilation.

 

Option D It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth muscle: Is the property of vasodilators.

questions.text: Xerophthalmia/ conjunctival xerosis occurs due to deficiency of which of the following vitamin:  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin A

 

Explanation

 

Xerophthalmia, including conjunctival xerosis (dryness of the conjunctiva), is a hallmark sign of Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the maintenance of healthy epithelial tissues, including the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye. It also plays a crucial role in vision, particularly in low-light conditions. Deficiency can lead to dryness of the eye, night blindness, and in severe cases, can progress to keratomalacia and blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1: Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. It does not typically manifest as xerophthalmia or conjunctival xerosis, which are eye-related conditions.

 

Option B. Vitamin B3: Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While dermatitis can affect the skin around the eyes, it does not cause xerophthalmia, which is specifically related to dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with bone diseases like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults due to its role in calcium and phosphate metabolism. It is not typically associated with xerophthalmia or eye disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eye manifestations of vitamin a deficiency:

 

  • Night Blindness or Nyctalopia -The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light.
  • Xerophthalmia- conjunctival and corneal dryness
  • Bitot's Spots - greyish-white triangular plaques adherent to the conjunctiva.
  • All the above-mentioned ocular changes are completely reversible with vitamin A supplementation.
  • Keratomalacia -softening of the cornea

 

Table: WHO Vitamin A deficiency grading

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 536

choices.text: Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen.
Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus.
Palpation begins at the site of pain.
Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe abdominal pain. Identify the false statement given about the examination of the abdomen: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palpation begins at the site of pain.

 

Palpation in the examination of a patient with abdominal pain should never start at the site of pain. Instead, it should begin away from the painful area to avoid causing the patient unnecessary discomfort and to prevent muscle guarding that might obscure findings. This approach allows the examiner to gather information about the non-painful areas first and approach the painful site last, ensuring a more accurate and less distressing examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen: This statement is correct. Hemoperitoneum, which is bleeding into the peritoneal cavity, can cause reddish or purplish discoloration on the flanks, known as Grey Turner’s sign. This is a significant indicator of internal bleeding, particularly in cases of acute pancreatitis or trauma.

 

Option B. Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus: This statement is correct. Cullen’s sign is the appearance of bluish discoloration around the umbilicus, which indicates intraperitoneal hemorrhage. It is often associated with conditions such as ruptured ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation: This statement is correct. Guarding (voluntary or involuntary muscle contraction) and rigidity (a constant, board-like hardness of the abdominal muscles) are classic signs of peritoneal irritation or inflammation, such as that seen in peritonitis. These signs suggest that there may be an underlying acute inflammatory or infectious process in the abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining a patient with abdominal pain, always begin palpation away from the site of pain to ensure a more accurate and less distressing assessment.

questions.text: A patient developed sudden hypertensive episode after taking wine. He is suffering from a psychiatric illness and is on medications for the same. Which is the drug he is likely to be using? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MAOIs

 

The patient in the question is likely taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) for his psychiatric illness.

 

MAOIs are known to cause a "Cheese reaction" or hypertensive crisis when combined with tyramine-rich foods like wine, cheese, and pizzas. Normally, tyramine is broken down by monoamine oxidase enzymes in the body. However, when a person is taking MAOIs, these enzymes are inhibited, leading to an accumulation of tyramine. The excess tyramine can cause a sudden and dangerous increase in blood pressure, resulting in a hypertensive episode.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors): Incorrect. SSRIs work by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and do not significantly affect the metabolism of tyramine.

 

Option C. SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors): Incorrect. SNRIs work by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine and do not significantly affect the metabolism of tyramine.

 

Option D. TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants): Incorrect. While TCAs can have some effects on blood pressure, they do not inhibit monoamine oxidase enzymes and do not lead to the accumulation of tyramine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) can cause a "cheese reaction" or hypertensive crisis when combined with tyramine-rich foods like wine, cheese, and pizzas due to the inhibition of monoamine oxidase enzymes and the accumulation of tyramine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lethargy

 

Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration. In the context of dehydration, it is important to differentiate between signs that indicate mild to moderate (some) dehydration and those that suggest severe dehydration. Lethargy indicates a more serious state of fluid loss that affects the child's overall responsiveness and energy levels, which is not characteristic of mild or moderate dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: This sign can occur in both some and severe dehydration. When the skin, typically on the abdomen or arm, is pinched and it returns to its original position slowly, it indicates decreased skin turgor, a common sign of dehydration.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: Sunken eyes can be a symptom of both some and severe dehydration. It is a visible sign that reflects reduced fluid in the body, causing the eyes to appear sunken.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because one of the choices (lethargy) is not a sign of some dehydration but rather severe dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:


Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: A 39 year G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. Which of the following is a complete contra-indication to cerclage? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured membranes

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ruptured Membranes:
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.

 

Absolute Contraindications to Cervical Cerclage

 

  • Active labor
  • Clinical signs of chorioamnionitis
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Fetal demise (IUFD)
  • Major fetal anomalies incompatible with life
  • Significant vaginal bleeding due to placental abruption
  • ruptured membranes 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates an increased risk of preterm labor but is not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. This test measures the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that acts as a "glue" during pregnancy, keeping the amniotic sac attached to the lining of the uterus.

 

Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina: While bulging membranes present a high-risk situation, they are not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. In some cases, cerclage can still be performed with careful management.

 

Option D. Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is not a contraindication to cerclage. While it may increase the overall risk profile of the pregnancy, it does not specifically contraindicate the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cervical cerclage due to the increased risk of infection and complications.

 

Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not an OCD related disorder?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Temper tantrums

 

Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders include conditions that share features with OCD, such as repetitive behaviors or obsessive thoughts.

 

Temper tantrums, on the other hand, are emotional outbursts seen typically in children and are not directly related to OCD or its spectrum disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hair pulling disorder (Trichotillomania): Hair pulling disorder (Trichotillomania) is characterized by repetitive hair pulling resulting in hair loss.

 

Option C. Hoarding disorder: Hoarding disorder is characterized by persistent difficulty discarding possessions, leading to clutter.

 

Option D. Skin picking (Excoriation disorder): Skin picking (Excoriation disorder) involves recurrent skin picking resulting in skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 418-436.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with abdominal pain. Evaluation revealed the presence of renal calculi and high PTH levels. What should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tc-99m Sestamibi

 

The patient has elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels and renal calculi, which suggests primary hyperparathyroidism. The next step in the management of primary hyperparathyroidism is to localize the overactive parathyroid gland(s). This is most effectively done using a Tc-99m Sestamibi scan. The Sestamibi scan helps in identifying the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland by detecting increased uptake of the radioactive tracer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound thyroid: While useful for identifying thyroid nodules, ultrasound thyroid is not the best tool for localizing hyperactive parathyroid glands in primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. DEXA scan: DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) scan is used to assess bone density and diagnose osteoporosis. While osteoporosis can be a consequence of hyperparathyroidism, the DEXA scan is not used to localize the hyperactive parathyroid glands.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine uptake study:  This study is used primarily for evaluating thyroid function, particularly in cases of primary hyperthyroidism, to determine the pattern of iodine uptake in the thyroid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with primary hyperparathyroidism indicated by high PTH levels and renal calculi, a Tc-99m Sestamibi scan is the appropriate next step to localize the overactive parathyroid gland(s).

questions.text:
Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. DiGeorge syndrome
  2. Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome
  3. Ataxia telangiectasia
  4. Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 only

 

Live vaccinations are generally contraindicated in individuals with certain immunodeficiency disorders because their immune systems may not be able to handle the attenuated (weakened) pathogens in the vaccines, potentially leading to severe infections. However, there are exceptions based on the nature of the immunodeficiency.

 

  • Complement deficiency: This is a condition where components of the complement system (a part of the immune system) are deficient. Complement deficiencies do not affect the cellular immune response significantly, meaning that the risk of adverse effects from live vaccinations is not increased. Therefore, individuals with complement deficiency can receive live vaccines safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome involves a defect in T-cell production due to thymic hypoplasia. Since T-cells are crucial for mounting an immune response to vaccines, live vaccines are contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: This is a condition characterized by defects in both the immune system and DNA repair mechanisms. Patients with this condition have a higher risk of developing severe infections from live vaccines, so they are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting both the immune system and platelet production. Individuals with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome are at risk for severe infections from live vaccines due to their compromised immune function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.

 

However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

choices.text: The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of pterygium? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rate of recurrence is 95%

 

  • Pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue.
  • It is caused by prolonged exposure to UV rays, dry heat, etc.
  • It has three parts: head (apical part on the cornea, body (region between limbus and canthus), and cap (semilunar white infiltrate in front of the head).
  • Patients may experience itching and grittiness due to Dellen.
  • It can interfere with vision and induce astigmatism.
  • Stocker's line may be associated with pterygium, which is a linear deposition of iron seen in the corneal epithelium, anterior to the head of a pterygium.
  • The recurrence rate after simple surgical excision is around 80%.

 

 

  • Pterygium is of 2 types: 
    1. Progressive which is thick, fleshy, and vascular.
    2. Regressive which is thin, atrophic, and attenuated.
  • This condition can be treated symptomatically with tear substitutes for dry eye symptoms and patients are advised to avoid  exposure to sun.
  • Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred treatment to avoid recurrence.
  • The recurrence rate of pterygium is around 80% after simple surgical excision. Excision together with adjunctive therapies such as mitomycin C or 5-fluorouracil can reduce the risk of recurrence to approximately 10%.
  • Reported Recurrence rate after P.E.R.F.E.C.T technique is 1.6% (Cornelius CR. Recurrence Rate and Complications of Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a fibrovascular growth: This is accurate. Pterygium consists of fibrovascular tissue that can progressively invade the cornea.

 

Option C. The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap: This is true. The pterygium is typically described as having three parts: the head (which is the part that extends onto the cornea), the body (the main bulk of the growth), and the cap or leading edge.

 

Option D. Has progressive and regressive types: This is also true. Pterygium can be classified into progressive, which is active, vascular, and may encroach further onto the cornea, and regressive, which is typically less vascular and more fibrotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium's recurrence after surgical removal depends greatly on the surgical technique and the use of adjuvant therapies, not inherently 95% as previously thought. Effective management includes surgical excision combined with conjunctival autografts and adjuvant therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence significantly.

questions.text: In context of biliary atresia, what is the typical duration of jaundice observed in infants? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 weeks 

 

Biliary atresia typically presents with jaundice that is not evident at birth but becomes apparent within the first two weeks of life. Jaundice lasting longer than two weeks in a newborn can be indicative of biliary atresia, especially if it is conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2 Months: While jaundice in biliary atresia often becomes noticeable after the first two weeks of life, it would likely persist and not resolve on its own, prompting further investigation well before two months of age if it is due to biliary atresia.

 

Option C. 2 years: Jaundice due to biliary atresia would be identified and treated well before a child reaches two years of age. If left untreated, biliary atresia can lead to liver failure within the first two years of life.

 

Option D. 48 hours: Physiological jaundice of the newborn typically appears within the first 24 to 72 hours after birth and resolves without treatment. Jaundice persisting beyond this period, especially if it's conjugated jaundice, requires further evaluation for pathological causes, including biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Persistent jaundice extending beyond two weeks of age in an infant can be indicative of biliary atresia and warrants prompt investigation and potential surgical intervention.

questions.text: Which is NOT a hyper-estrogenic condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Low BMI

 

Explanation:

 

Hyper-estrogenic conditions are characterized by elevated levels of estrogen. Such conditions can arise due to various factors, including hormonal imbalances, medications, and specific medical conditions.


Low BMI: This is not typically associated with high estrogen levels. In fact, individuals with low BMI may have lower estrogen levels due to decreased adipose tissue, which is a source of estrogen production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tamoxifen use: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used primarily in the treatment of breast cancer. It can act as an estrogen agonist in certain tissues, potentially leading to increased estrogenic effects.

 

Option C. Nulliparous: Nulliparous women (those who have never given birth) may have higher lifetime exposure to estrogen due to the absence of pregnancy and lactation periods, which would otherwise lower estrogen exposure.

 

Option D. Ovarian cancer: Certain types of ovarian cancer can lead to increased estrogen production, contributing to a hyper-estrogenic state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low BMI is not associated with hyper-estrogenic conditions.

 

High estrogen levels are more likely to be seen in conditions such as Tamoxifen use, nulliparity, and certain types of ovarian cancer.

 

High estrogen is a risk factors for fibroids, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma and endometriosis.

questions.text: Structures passing between marked points A and B? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stylopharyngeus

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts into the pharyngeal wall. It is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) and functions to elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speaking.

 

 

 

The gaps in the pharyngeal wall and structures passing thorugh them

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palatopharyngeus: This muscle runs from the soft palate to the pharynx, but it does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. Instead, it is involved in forming the palatopharyngeal arch.

 

Option C. Stylohyoid: This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts onto the hyoid bone. It is involved in elevating the hyoid bone during swallowing but does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Option D. Mylohyoid: This muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is involved in elevating the floor of the mouth during swallowing. It does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors, and it is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).

questions.text: Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders has a high chance of catalase positive organisms causing infections?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex. This defect impairs the ability of phagocytes to produce reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for killing certain bacteria and fungi. As a result, individuals with CGD are particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms, which can neutralize hydrogen peroxide and thus evade destruction by the impaired phagocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgE syndrome: Also known as Job syndrome, this disorder is characterized by high levels of IgE, recurrent skin abscesses, pneumonia, and characteristic facial features. It is not specifically associated with increased infections by catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Bruton disease: Also known as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, this condition affects B cell development, leading to low levels of immunoglobulins and increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, but not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency. While patients have an increased risk of infections, the susceptibility to catalase-positive organisms is not as pronounced as in CGD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic granulomatous disease is associated with a high risk of infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex, which impairs the killing of these organisms by phagocytes.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - Lamina propria 

 

Is an incorrect match because the structure labelled 4 shows the basement membrane rather than the lamina propria.

 

The image shows irregular cells attached to the basement membrane and is of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (marked as 4 in the image). It appears to have multiple layers. There is, however, only one layer of cells. The multi-layered appearance is caused by the nuclei of epithelial cells (shown as 3 in the image) being located at different levels.1`

 

The epithelium shows hair-like projections called cilia (marked as 1 in the image) and goblet cells (marked as 2 in the image). Goblet cells secrete mucous which helps to trap dust entering the passages. The cilia are capable of movement and help in the clearance of mucous

 

Example include epithelium lining the trachea and in large bronchi.

 

Other Options:

 

1- Cilia: These are the hair-like projections visible at the top of the epithelial cells, which help in moving mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory passages.

 

2- Goblet cells: These cells are interspersed between the epithelial cells and are responsible for producing mucus. They appear as clear, expanded cells at the level marked "2."

 

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell: The nuclei shown here are located at different heights within the cells, giving the epithelium a pseudostratified appearance.

 

4- Basement membrane: This layer supports the epithelium and is incorrectly labeled as the lamina propria in the options. It is a thin, fibrous structure evident just below the epithelial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure in the image are

 

1- Cilia

2- Goblet cell

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell

4- Basement membrane

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a mobile, rubbery mass in her left breast. A histological image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis for the given image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma 

 

The finding of mobile breast and the histological image showing a mixture of stromal and epithelial tissue, often described as having a 'staghorn’ appearance is seen in fibroadenoma.

 

This is a common benign tumor of the breast, usually presenting as a mobile, rubbery mass. Histologically, it shows a mixture of stromal and epithelial tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC): This is the most common type of breast cancer. Histologically, IDC typically shows abnormal, invasive glandular cells that originate from the ducts and invade surrounding breast tissue.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: This is a rare breast tumor that can be benign or malignant. Histologically, it is similar to fibroadenoma but typically shows increased stromal cellularity and leaf-like projections. It is not mobile.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma in-situ (LCIS): LCIS is a non-invasive condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lobules of the breast. Histologically, it shows small, uniform cells that fill and expand the lobules.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fibroadenoma is the likely diagnosis of a mobile, rubbery breast mass in a young woman, characterized histologically by a benign proliferation of stromal and epithelial components.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A.

 

 

Image A shows Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) and it can be used in managing B/L external auditory canal atresia.

 

INDICATIONS FOR BAHA

 

  1. When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
  2. Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.
  3. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.
  4. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.
  5. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated.
  6. Single-sided hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cochlear implant is an electronic device that can provide useful hearing and improved communication abilities for persons who have severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

 

Cochlear implants may be used both in children and adults. The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy piston is used in otosclerosis patients.

 

Option D. Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis is used to replace the incudo-stapedial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with bilateral external auditory canal atresia, BAHA is an excellent management option, leveraging bone conduction to bypass the outer and middle ear, thus facilitating hearing when traditional air-conduction devices cannot be used.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male presented with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following anti-diabetic drug acts by causing glucosuria? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin, as an SGLT2 inhibitor, is the drug among the options provided that acts specifically by causing glucosuria. This mechanism is unique to SGLT2 inhibitors and is a direct way of lowering blood glucose levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus. The other drugs listed work through different mechanisms that do not involve the induction of glucosuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarbose: This drug is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It works by slowing down the digestion of carbohydrates in the intestine, thereby reducing the rise in blood glucose after meals. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Option B. Glipizide: Glipizide is a sulfonylurea. It works by stimulating insulin release from the pancreatic beta cells. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor. It works by increasing the levels of incretin hormones, which increase insulin release and decrease glucagon release in a glucose-dependent manner. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 (Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter-2) inhibitor, works by blocking glucose reabsorption in the kidney, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine, i.e., glucosuria.

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

 

FIBROUS DYSPLASIA

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly of bone formation.
  • The hallmark is replacement of normal bone and marrow by fibrous tissue and small woven spicules of bone.
  • Fibrous dysplasia can occur in the epiphysis, metaphysis, or diaphysis.
  • It may affect one bone (monostotic form) or several bones (polyostotic form).
  • The monostotic form is the most common and is usually diagnosed in patients between 20 and 30 years of age. It most commonly affects the femur.
  • The polyostotic form typically manifests in children <10 years of age and may progress with age. It most commonly affects the maxilla and other craniofacial bones.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome refers to polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cutaneous pigmentation (café au lait spots), and endocrine abnormalities (Precoceous puberty).
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” borders).
  • Fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur has shepherd crook deformity.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.

 

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity (looks like shepherds stick which is crooked in shape) bone is replaced by fibrous tissue in fibrous dysplasia.

  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim, called ‘Rind sign’.

     

 

A. Shepherd Crook deformity; B. Rind sign 

 

  • Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).
    • On biopsy, Chinese Letter Pattern is recognised.
    • Surgical treatment (Curettage + bone grafting) is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blade of grass deformity. The blade of grass sign, also called the candle flame sign, refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen during the lytic phase of Paget disease of bone. The lytic, or incipient active, phase of the disease is characterized by intense osteoclastic activity that is exhibited on radiographs as osteolysis. In the long bones, osteolysis is manifested as a characteristic metaphyseal to diaphyseal wedge-shaped area of radiolucency that assumes the configuration of a flame or blade of grass. This advancing wedge of osteolysis, which begins in the subchondral bone of the epiphysis and extends peripherally into the metaphysis and diaphysis, spreads about 1 cm per year and shows no marginal sclerosis. A potential pitfall is misdiagnosing the track sign of the femur as the blade of grass sign.

 

 

Option C. Chicken wire appearance. Histopathologically, cellular areas in chondroblastoma are composed of “chondroblasts” with an oval to round nucleus and with well-defined eosinophilic cytoplasm. A fine network of pericellular calcification called “chicken wire calcification” are seen in the cytoplasm or stroma some cases.

 

 

Option D. Corduroy appearance. Hemangioma is a common benign bone lesion. It is estimated that 10% of the population has asymptomatic hemangioma of the vertebral bodies. Hemangiomas also are common in the skull. They usually are discovered as incidental findings. The radiographic appearance in the spine usually is characteristic, with thickened, vertically oriented trabeculae giving the classic “jailhouse” (Corduroy) appearance. In cross-section, these thickened trabeculae have a “polka dot” pattern on CT scan.

 

Treatment usually is not necessary.

 

 

Polka dot appearance on CT scan

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Chronic starvation except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperthermia

 

In chronic starvation, the body undergoes various changes due to prolonged lack of nutrients. Hyperthermia (increased body temperature) is not associated with chronic starvation; instead, hypothermia (decreased body temperature) is more likely due to the body's reduced metabolic rate and insulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exhaustion: Commonly seen due to lack of energy intake.

 

Option C. Heart Atrophy: Occurs as the body breaks down muscle tissue, including cardiac muscle, for energy.

 

Option D. Hypotension: Common due to reduced blood volume and overall weakened condition.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alcian blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
It is a reversible cell adaptation

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Barrett's esophagus?(NEET  PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucus-secreting foveolar cells are characteristic

 

Mucus-secreting foveolar cells are characteristic: This statement is not true. Foveolar cells are a feature of the normal gastric mucosa, and their presence in biopsy specimens from the esophagus is not characteristic of Barrett's esophagus. Mucus-secreting goblet cells (not foveolar cells) are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus: This statement is true. Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium with intestinal features.

 

Option C. Alcian blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimens: This statement is true. Alcian blue is a stain used to detect the presence of acid mucins in tissue samples, which are a feature of the columnar epithelium seen in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. It is a reversible cell adaptation: This statement is true. As all metaplasia are reversible, Barrett's esophagus is also reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is characterized by intestinal metaplasia of the esophageal epithelium, specifically with goblet cells, and is diagnosed using Alcian blue staining.

questions.text: A dead body is brought for postmortem examination with stellate shaped gunshot wound and muzzle imprint. What can be the distance? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contact shot

 

The presence of a stellate (star-shaped) gunshot wound with a muzzle imprint is indicative of a contact shot.

 

key factor in determining the range of fire -

 

  • Singeing (due to burning of hair/ flame).
  • Blackening (smoke deposits – burnt gun powder).
  • Tattooing (embedding of unburnt gunpowder particles)
  • Muzzle imprint is the imprint of the firearm – only in the contact shot

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Close range: Incorrect because close range typically has blackening and tattooing around the wound but lacks the distinct stellate pattern and muzzle imprint seen in contact shots.

 

Option C. Intermediate Range: Incorrect as intermediate range wounds show only tattooing without singeing, blackening, or muzzle imprint.

 

Option D. Distant Range: Incorrect as distant range wounds do not have any of the features mentioned above (singeing, blackening, tattooing, stellate pattern, or muzzle imprint).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a stellate shaped wound with a muzzle imprint indicates a contact shot. This is a crucial finding in forensic examinations to determine the distance of the firearm at the time of discharge.

 

Key points to understand about gunshot wounds and range of fire:

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to OPD with swelling in the upper part of the tibia. X-ray revealed periosteal reaction in upper diaphysis of tibia. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario, immunohistochemistry showing positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 with histopath image showing small round blue cells, points to a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is an osteoid forming tumor. Patient usually complains of Night pain. But it neither shows small round blue cells on biopsy nor is positive for MIC-2

 

Option C. Metastatic neuroblastoma: Metastatic neuroblastoma also shows Homer wright pseudo rosettes, but it is positive for NSE, PHOX 28.

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma (Giant cell tumor): Osteoclastoma is a benign, locally aggressive bone tumor that is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells on biopsy. It typically affects the epiphysis of long bones and does not present with small round blue cells or positive staining for MIC-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing sarcoma is a small round blue cell tumor commonly occurring in the diaphysis of long bones in adolescents. It is characterized by positive immunohistochemical staining for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 (CD99).

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2390-2391
